Posts.Content: Hi Shirl3 I think it is quite common for people to take a short break in chemo, especially when you’ve had a tough time! Mine was halted after the first chemo in June, following sepsis and recommenced post surgery in Sept. The chemo nurses and my Onc say it’s a common thing to have a short break so if that’s what you want then bring it up and ask the question :-) Good Luck and fingers crossed for no more hospital visits!!.. for both of us!!  Jackie xx
Posts.Title: Delaying treatment

Posts.Content: Well I can’t believe I made it this far, I had  chemo 6 of 6 yesterday! 3 FEC and 3 T. I can’t say which was worse, I had horrific side effects with both, and I’m still apprehensively waiting for the Tax Truck to arrive again on Saturday!  We looked a right pair in the chemo suite, determined to try and reduce various side effects! I sucked on ice cubes the whole time, to avoid the mouth ulcers (worked great so far) and had my bare feet on frozen sweet corn and peas and my hands on frozen ice pods to help prevent Palmer Planter Erythrodysesthesia and reduce neuropathy! I had severe heel pain and unable to walk for 4 days in round 1 of T, but reduced dose and a ton of cream and reduced walking paid off in round 2. I now have a large, but dry, skin blister on my right heel.. Id put piccys up but I only use my phone to post! On T round 2 I also suffered a week of slightly swollen bright burning red itchy cheeks from day 9 for 7 days. Nothing would help neither piriton nor cream. The chemo nurses and Onc hadn’t heard of this side effect before, so I’m interested to hear if anyone else had it? I reckon it was similar to the heel issue, so we also pressed cold packs to my cheeks during chemo, I don’t care how silly I looked LOL  I finally had a chemo round with no A&E visits last time and I desperately hope that’s the same this time!! I’m also so done with the flippin nose bleeds! I have my extra steroids, lenograstim injections, gabapentin, Loratadine, lansaprozole etc and this time I have some added tongue drops and pills for when my tongue goes white and the burning down my oesophagus!  Fingers crossed that the major side effects are finished by Christmas Day so I can enjoy my dinner and taste it, oh and be able to cut it up as I’m struggling with using a knife in my right hand!  ‘Just’ axillary node clearance surgery in Jan and radiotherapy to go, I can’t believe this awful ordeal lasts a whole year! But looking forward to Christmas :-)  Jackie x
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: Hi HopeRu I’ve just checked back through my notes to my first T and my worst pains were Sun-Tue after chemo on Wed, so day 5-7, then they started to subside so I really hope yours is starting to lessen now! When we are in the midst of chemo, it really seems like forever doesn’t it and each day or hour that passes when we feel rubbish can bring us down very low and you just can’t imagine feeling well or that it will actually pass, it does every time and this will be the same and this time next week you will be a different person I’m sure of it!!!  I don’t know if you have a PICC line or not but that gave me a weekly opportunity to speak to the chemo nurses when it was being flushed, so I got hold of some Gabapentin much earlier than when I saw my Onc, so I could start it a week before my second cycle, you could call them and let them know you are in a lot of pain and need something stronger/different, I’m sure they will help!  One more injection to go tomorrow thank goodness, that also marks a turning point in wellness :-)  Keep going buddy xxx
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: Fantastic news HopeRu :-) It’s been a long 11 days!! It always feels like you’ll never feel better again then suddenly you do :-) and with enough time to get into the Christmas spirit!  I found there is definitely a set of week one side effects and a different set for week two. The nose bleeds always started in week 2 for me and they only stopped a few days before my next chemo! The tingling in my fingers started in round one and subsided towards the next chemo, but it has got progressively worse with each round and this last round it has been quite bad. I can’t do anything that requires any dexterity or use of finger tips and fingers, it’s quite frustrating! This round I have also found that I get nerve pulling sensation in my arms and legs, I dont really know how to describe it, kind of like youve over extended an arm or leg and you’ve pulled on a nerve?! I’m told these symptoms are very common and that for most people they recover but it might take a few months!  As well as nosebleeds the other week 2 side effect I’m getting is streaming eyes, I look like Im crying all the time! And my eyes are a bit red and sore, again that always stops a few days before the next chemo! My lips also take a beating so I’m using lots of lip cream as well! How is your mouth doing? I found that week one my tongue goes white and taste goes and week 2 the colour comes back but the inside of your mouth goes rough and takes a good few days to go smooth again and about now Day 12-14 it’s feeling more normal again :-) my taste is still a bit off though!  I hope the cold is behaving and doesn’t get a grip that’s the last thing you need on top of this. It’s s tricky season to have to go through chemo, everyone seems to have a cold!  I seem to have been spared the itchy hot face this round thank goodness!! So I reckon the cold packs did work after all :-) Somehow I have managed to keep some eyebrows and upper eyelashes although I’m tempting fate by saying that ha-ha I had threatened to use a Pritt Stick to keep them in place ha-ha  My heels are currently in a right state, the giant blisters that formed after the awful Palmar-Planter symptoms in round 1 are now peeling off, fortunately there are no open areas so I’m slapping more cream on and being very careful about keeping them covered.  I’m now on the count down to Wednesday!!! 3 days to my next blood test AND hopefully if all is OK the removal of the PICC line!!! It’s been in since my first chemo way back st the beginning of June!! I also get to see the surgeon to discuss my second surgery!  Jackie xx
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: Hi HopeRu For the T part, I was told to take the steroids in the morning and evening with food and exactly 12hrs apart to give the best coverage, this does mean that you are taking a dose in the evening which may keep you awake, but I’d rather that and have a better spread out dose! I took them the day before, the day of chemo and the day after. For cycle 2 I needed extra and had two more days of a lower dose and will do again for cycle 3. I had severe side effects and found the normal painkillers weren’t strong enough and had Gabapentin for cycle 2. You have to start it a week in advance to get it in your system.  T, unlike FEC, typically doesn’t make you feel nauseous but it can do. I was told to take 1x8mg  ondansetron tab before the chemo and also we are still given the 3 day Emend Aprepritant course. However, I had awful nausea with FEC which persisted for 2-2.5weeks each cycle and I have suffered no nausea at all on T (thank goodness!). I sucked ice cubes (with a bit of juice in) the whole time it was having T and also had my hands on ice packs, to help prevent mouth sores and and also reduce potential neuropathy. I was also told to keep my hands as still as possible as there was anecdotal evidence to suggest that helps reduce it too.  I was also told to wear dark nail polish to help reduce UV light getting to your nails as T can damage them. I also wear a thin pair of black gloves when I go out!  Lastly, I use lots of thick moisturiser, I found I shed a layer of skin each cycle like after you’ve had a sun tan.  Best of luck for next week, I hope you have minimal side effects :-) I have my final dose on Wednesday!  Jackie x
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: Awe HopeRu :-( I’m so sorry you clearly have taken a mighty whack from the Tax Truck!! I TOTALLY know what you are going through, that first one really was utterly brutal but IT WILL PASS!!!! I have found the first painful set of side effects declined after a week as you say, when you stop the injections, but I had a few days were it was excruciating, I’d say you need gabapentin!! Ask your chemo nurses for it, start taking it straight away I’m on x3 a day through this painful bit and then stay on a maintenance dose all the way through just upping it for this bad week. It takes a while to build up in your system and you feel a bit drunk and dozy at first but that wears off. It’s worth it!! Write down every side effect and tell your Onc, there is room to reduce the dose without compromising your prognosis, that has made a massive difference to me! I have zero taste this first week as well, my tongue goes white and swollen along with my throat! I’ve tried the Nystatin tongue drops but they haven’t made any difference! But, this happened in both the last two cycles and each time the tongue starts to recover after a week!  My nose was also bloody as you have described but it was only in the second week I started to get nose bleeds! They stopped, both times, at the end of 3 weeks just prior to next chemo.  Is your face red hot and itchy or just very bad hot flushes as they are also a nightmare at the mo! I tried everything on my face but nothing worked, but some little frozen ice packs bring a bit of relief!  My fingers and toes and hands and nails are also numb but tingly and I’m struggling to use them, that did improve towards the end of each cycle.  I really feel for you and wish I could reach out and give you a hug! This part is so so miserable BUT based on my last two cycles I am convinced we will be feeling so much better in two weeks, just hang on in there one day at a time! we will enjoy our Christmas!  Keep talking and venting on here and let us know how you’re doing! (((Hugs))) Jackie xxx
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: Well it’s gone very quite on here! How is everyone doing?  I’ve found my final round of T has totally wiped me out, I can’t seem to stay awake! My fingers are quite numb now, my tongue is white and taste gone, throat and back of tongue are a bit swollen and the tenderness round my neck and upper back has returned! Hoping things will subside about Thursday and really hope I don’t get the red hot face issues and nose bleeds for week 2!  Time for injection no.4 Then I am determined to get out of bed and try and put the poor Christmas tree up, which has been sat in the hall in its netting like a sausage since Monday LOL Its beautiful and snowy here, how Id love to be hiking across the fields in it right now!  Hope everyone is doing OK and managing to fend off their side effects!!  Jackie x
Posts.Title: * * * December Breast Cancer Chemo Club * * *

Posts.Content: Hiya, hope all goes well tomorrow and I think it's great you feel this way, don't question it, go with it!  I'm have a left breast mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy on Friday. Until this week I had been bobbing along ok despite having started chemo, had one round, developed a tooth abscess which resulted in neutropenic sepsis and ended up in hospital for a week and the tooth being pulled out. It was deemed too dangerous for chemo to continue so in the meantime they changed my treatment plan and I suddenly find myself facing surgery instead. During the course of the last week my mental state has taken a nose dive and I've been scared and low and frightened of the life changing surgery that is to come. It's made me feel depressed, angry and very anxious. I just can't seem switch into positive mode no matter what I do! I would much prefer to be in a state of denial. So don't question your mood, just go with it and let it protect you :-) really good luck for tomorrow xx
Posts.Title: Why am I not nervous

Posts.Content: Firstly, what a nightmare being passed around like that! I found it very unsettling when I had to switch surgeons after developing a rapport with my first one!  I would definitely opt for surgery 1st! Unfortunately, I wasn't given that option and wasn't aware I could challenge it, so my plan was supposed to be chemo first. At the original testing stage the ultrasound showed no indication of spread to the lymph nodes and all was quite positive. I had 3 tumours; one 21mm and two smaller ones only 3mm each. I was told I would need a mastectomy regardless of whether chemo shrunk them or not. So I started chemo FEC-T and had one round. Sadly I developed a wisdom tooth abcess which resulted in serious infection (sepsis) and I was hospitalised for a week and had to have the tooth out. Chemo was stopped as it was too dangerous for me to continue at that point. I then had several weeks to recover while they scheduled me for surgery instead. I had my mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy 2 weeks ago. The results are that 3months on from diagnosis the tumours had grown to 24mm and the two tiny ones had coalesced into one 16mm tumour and the cancer has spread to my lymph nodes, I am now having scans to see if it has spread elsewhere in my body and I will need more surgery to remove all of my lymph nodes. I truly feel that chemo first is a dangerous option. a) chemo is an unknown quantity and effects everyone individually, in some cases it may not even work on your cancer because we don't do DNA sequencing of the tumours to determine what definitely will and won't work! Therefore it may allow the cancer to grow and spread b) if there are complications with chemo it is delayed or stopped for periods of time, as in my case, also allowing an aggressive cancer to grow and spread.  Cut the damn thing out as early as possible, then whack it with chemo! That would be my advice and I wish I had been given that option at the start as surgery first seems the most sensible and logical option to me!  Jackie
Posts.Title: Offered choice of chemo before mastectomy or after - what would you...

Posts.Content: Hi Lilyrose Yup as others have said, very common to have bone and CT scans! I had the same diagnosis as you and my 2 tumours were slightly bigger than yours! I had 2/5 nodes involved and was sent for scans. I have to say that was my blackest time waiting for the results for those, so I understand your worry and apprehension as we all do. My scans were also clear. Keep yourself occupied doing things to distract yourself as best you can, try and shut out the dark thoughts which is very hard to do I know. We are all here for you!  (((Hugs))) Jackie x
Posts.Title: Scans to check if bc has spread

Posts.Content: Yes most likely the steroids! I was told that is particularly the case when having Docetaxel (Taxotere) as you have higher dose steroids. They have been affectionately termed bitchoids LOL the chemo nurses warned my partner that most people get rather ‘fractious’ thanks to the steroids and to be prepared! Jackie x
Posts.Title: Steroids or chemo

Posts.Content: I'm sure this question has been asked a million times sorry! But which is my best option of vein, PICC or port? I have read horror stories on FB cancer pages for all 3 options so a I thought I'd ask the question on here. I'm seeing the chemo nurse today ahead of my first chemo session on Thursday! No matter how strong and positive I try to be the fear is rising! Any links to previous threads or posts or comments gratefully received thanks :-)
Posts.Title: Cannula vs PICC vs Port??

Posts.Content: Hi Mimi Yes I’ve had surgery, mastectomy in July sadly it has spread to my lymph nodes so I will require more surgery after chemo and radiotherapy :-(  With T, one of the potential side effects is peripheral neuropathy which is damage to your nerves in your hands and feet, to help prevent this some people try and ice them during chemo to prevent a high dose of T getting to their hands and feet. It’s common practise in the US and some NHS trusts and private do it here. It’s  the same principle as the cold cap to prevent hair loss, it’s not a guarantee, but I swear it has saved my hands and sucking on ice helps prevent your mouth from sores and ulcers etc I didn’t ice my feet and I’ve had really bad palmar-plantar problems in my heels and have not been able to walk properly, so I will be icing hands, feet and mouth next time! We take a cool bag and I use my bunnies frozen ice pods (they use them in the summer :-)) and the ice cube bags which are a good size for your mouth, I add a bit of squash for flavour, and for my feet I will be taking some value/smart price frozen peas I’m gonna look a right numpty but I don’t care ha-ha-ha  I was doing a half hour walk every day to try and boost my mood but I haven’t been able to do that and next cycle I am going to stay off my feet as much as possible for the first week, until the chemo in my body has significantly reduced. I’ve also noticed my temp is elevated a lot more and on speaking to others that seems to be quite typical. So keep a good check on your temp, mine reached the 37.5 and resulted in an A&E visit but was just a spiking temp, but best to be on the safe side!  I have had a lot of side effects with this one and I’m happy to discuss if you want or when and if you get any, but fingers crossed you won’t get them :-)  Jackie xx
Posts.Title: Anxiety about next chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Marie I hope FEC 3 is being kind to you and you haven’t been too nauseous through the night and this morning! You are officially half way!!!!!! :-)  It is bizarre how everyone’s treatment is completely different there doesn’t seem to be any way to predict it at all! Did they see signs of lymph node involvement during your initial assessment for you to have a full clearance? Mine showed nothing but I had the full mastectomy, rather than lumpectomy, it’s odd isn’t it?! I’m sorry to hear you had a haematoema that must have been very scary! How did you know, was it very obvious? Im convinced something is lurking in the crease behind my knee as it keeps pinching?!  I actually started with chemo first in June, then got sepsis via tooth abscess, hospitalised for a week and my treatment had to change to surgery then back to chemo! All very stressful as is this whole process. Have I already mentioned all this? Sorry if I have LOL  I’m not very proficient with using this site so if you have any questions about T and I don’t find my way to where you’ve posted please feel free to message me :-)  Take care Jackie xx
Posts.Title: Anxiety about next chemo

Posts.Content: Yes I was/am terrified of the allergic reaction too, but fortunately it didn’t happen on cycle 1! Fingers crossed for the others! I have to say, sadly, I’ve been hit quite badly with a lot of side effects on T and it’s been rather unpleasant! But not everyone gets them, same as with FEC. I will be knocking back the gabapentin in advance of the next chemo! If I stay on track my last one is Dec 6th! When is your first one? I would definitely suck on ice cubes, wear some dark nail varnish and if you can, put your hands and feet on ice. It takes about the same about of time as FEC!  Jxx
Posts.Title: Anxiety about next chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Mimi567 I totally understand the chemo fear, to be honest it’s not an irrational fear, chemo is really not pleasant! I, like you and many of us, have a lot of anxiety surrounding chemo, I can feel mine building ahead of my 5th chemo and 2nd T next week. I take a small dose (1-2mg) of diazepam before each chemo and it really helps! My chemo team said that is perfectly OK and my GP prescribed it for me.  Keep telling yourself you are 2 chemos down, you know what to expect with FEC and this will mean you are half way through and this will be the last FEC, something to smile about, no more red juice!! :-) I always tell anyone taking my blood pressure that they cannot use my left arm and only offer them my right one, not all nurses will know that so it’s perfectly OK to tell them.  As far as veins are concerned they do take a beating with chemo and blood tests etc you can ask to have a PICC line or a port fitted. I had one fitted before I started chemo because I am needle phobic and because I wanted to preserve the veins on my right arm. The chemo nurses are trained to fit PICC lines its a quick painless procedure, where they locate a suitable vein in your upper arm and insert a tube along it and the end is fitted with a little port device that they can put the chemo through, take bloods etc and you don’t feel a thing it’s great! The only down side is you need to have it flushed with saline each week and redressed, they remove it after your last chemo. The other device is a PORT which works the same way but is situated in your chest. The majority I’ve seen are PICC lines. If you are really stressed and you think this may help, phone your chemo team and ask if they can fit you one ASAP (((Hugs))) Jackie xx
Posts.Title: Anxiety about next chemo

Posts.Content: Yup Docetaxel (Taxotere) is the culprit, it’s a common side effect. Mine started week 2 after the first ‘T’ chemo. It’s such a pain, spontaneous nose bleeds at any time of the day or night and a sore bloody nose that gets crusty blood scabs that you darent blow as it will bleed again grrr The only issue is if it won’t stop bleeding so it’s an A&E visit to check platelet count! I’ll try the Vaseline this time round!
Posts.Title: Nose sores!!

Posts.Content: A friend had gabapentin and said it worked much better than the OTC drugs. She was told to start it 2 days before each T cycle. I'm yet to go through that part of chemo and dreading it!
Posts.Title: Docetaxol and Clexane

Posts.Content: PICC lines are fantastic to have all chemo and bloods through, but a pain in the bum if you are sporty and active! I have been very very cautious with mine, but owing to a hiccup in treatment I had to stop chemo and have surgery before resuming chemo, they kept the PICC line in and it has hampered even my basic arm exercises post surgery! Even doing them gently the line has wriggled out 5cm! Which is now borderline for use. I’d defo consider the portacath as Toxophilite said and also agree, maintaining some of your normal physical activity is so so important for mental wellbeing during chemo and the rest of treatment!  Jackie x
Posts.Title: Picc Lines

Posts.Content: Hi Maz  I had similar diagnosis to you and had a mastectomy, absolutely no regrets! I wasn’t given an option but would have gone for mastectomy anyway for piece of mind.  Very best of luck, my scar looks fab and healed quickly and nicely, I’m also not bothering with reconstruction, my softie actually looks better than my remaining boob ha-ha  I hopefully have my last chemo on the 6th Dec as well, so we’ll both be good for Christmas celebrations, which was my goal yay! Have a fab time in the Dales enjoy every minute :-) Jackie xx
Posts.Title: I've made my mind up!

Posts.Content: Hi Lots of us have side effects with the bone marrow injections. The most common one is the bone ache, mine is in my thighs, others have it in sternum and hips etc My aches last beyond the period I take the injections for and subside gradually. The worst side effects I get with them is the ache and tenderness around my neck and shoulders which subsided during the first week but is very unpleasant! I didn’t get stomach cramps with mine, are you sure that’s not the chemo? Some chemo is renowned for causing cramps and diarrhoea!  As unpleasant as the injections are, its definitely worth putting up with for athe added protection, that’s what I told myself! Hope your next round is kinder  Jackie xx
Posts.Title: Side effects of bone marrow injection

Posts.Content: Hi I've been on Tamoxifen a few months and like others I've noticed significant different side effects on different brands. I want to ask my pharmacist for different brands to try so wondered if we had a list somewhere? I can see from searching there are rather a lot, it would be great if we could list them and do a poll to see which are the worst offenders. I've tried: Relonchem - SEs - fatigue, pmt like moods, deep hot flushes Wockhardt - SEs - significant eyesight change to long and near sight, aching painful joints, (more energy, reduced hot flushes, better mood)   What shall I try next, I cant survive a month on Relonchem so I want to phone the pharmacist and ask if he can order in something else ASAP. Cheers Jackie
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen brands UK list? trying to find one that suits me!

Posts.Content: Hi Linda Yes I've done a fair bit of Googling and Teva is definitely the one Id like to try. I phoned my pharmacist earlier and they said they cant order specific brands, it's just listed as Tamoxifen and they get what they get! I shall be asking a few other local pharmacies if they can get Teva and if so, I shall ask for my prescription to be directed to them. As you say we are on this for 10yrs I cant cope with this, I have crawled through today at work, my brain is struggling to recover as it is! I hope your GP can prescribe the Teva let me know how you get on with it :-) J
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen brands UK list? trying to find one that suits me!

Posts.Content: I also noticed some nausea and now take mine at night before bed, no more nausea!  Well it seems my pharmacy can order specific brands except they got confused and when I went in today they had TEVA on the banned list DOH!! So they are reordering a pack for me to try. Interesting a few of you said this made you feel fatigued, the fatigue is crippling me on RelonChem so I really hope that’s not the case when I switch over, I’m like a zombie at the moment! They offered me Genesis today but I don’t know anything about that one?!  Jackie
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen brands UK list? trying to find one that suits me!

Posts.Content: Hi Julie I noticed mine within the first few days and definitely within a week, but I react strongly and quickly to most drugs... chemo was such ‘fun’!!! Lol  Fingers crossed you don’t notice anything at all :-) Best wishes Jackie
Posts.Title: Tamoxifen brands UK list? trying to find one that suits me!

Posts.Content: Love my M&S bra I’m normally a 36B but with my lovely seroma etc I have to wear a 38A! I’ve ordered some more for my birthday :-)
Posts.Title: Post surgery bra sale online M&S

Posts.Content: Yes it’s all very individual, I was expecting 1-3 and had 5 removed! There is quite a variation in the numbers of lymph nodes we have in that area based on those that have had full node clearance!  Jackie x
Posts.Title: Senital node biopsy

Posts.Content: This is me!! Chemo is messing with my head I have had 3xFEC and I am currently sitting in reception of my chemo lounge waiting for chemo 4 which is Taxotere which I am terrified of, I have just taken some diazepam prescribed by my GP and okayed by oncologist and chemo nurses! It’s great stuff it really helps take the edge off! Call your GP ASAP they will help you, I’ve noticed they bend over backwards to help in this situation! Hang in there, when we look back at this I think we will be proud of ourselves for getting through what is a massively traumatic time and needing some help for anxiety and depression is totally ok and understandable! (((Hugs))) xxx
Posts.Title: Chemo induced anxiety & depression

Posts.Content: Following my mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy, despite being clinically negative at diagnosis (not visible in ultrasound or by feel) 2/5 nodes had small tumours. So I was told, following chemo, I would require axillary node clearance and then radiotherapy!  I have emotionally assimilated the cancer diagnosis and I am not bothered by being a baldy with no left boob BUT I cannot come to terms with requiring a full node clearance?! After a small amount of research it seems there are clinical trials underway to see if radiotherapy is just as good for long term prognosis as surgery and clearance! Radiotherapy also has the added benefit of a reduced risk of lymphodema which is ultimately my main concern as well as the fact i can not physically tolerate any more numb patches!  Please can I have thoughts on this? My Onc isn’t one for discussion and I don’t trust him to really consider what is best for me personally from a psychological and physical perspective; I’m just another number on his conveyor belt!  Does radiotherapy destroy nerves as much as having them cut in surgery? Will I still be numb regardless of which treatment I have? Will my lymph system still function if I only have radiotherapy? Any info gratefully received :-)  Thanks Jackie
Posts.Title: Axillary clearance or radiotherapy, what to do??
